Babe Ruth Is Lucky to Get Off So Easily After Hitting Umpire
IAR be it from us to wish any guy hard luck, but it appears that Babe Ruth

eschped too easily after his fight with Umpire Owens on the ball field. Ban
Sohnson dismissed the matter with a fine of $100 and a suspension of one week
This does not seem enough, and it is certain that a player of less importance
would have been treated rather harshly.
and a prolonged absence would have ruined Boston's pennant chances. Also the
gate receipts would have suffered. So Battling Ban became as meek as a lamb
and decided to “give the boy another chance.”

The bad feature of this case is that it will encourage others to pull the same
stuff. A week's layoff and $100 fine is nice, gentle punishment, and the chances
@re that some players would pay twice as much for a shot at an umpire’s jaw
Tt cost McGraw $500 for punching Byron under the grand stand and Ruth's of-
tense was more flagrant than that. Ban seems to have made another mistake.
He should. have used Ruth as a horrible example and soaked him with a long
layoff and a healthy fine a

ANS WAGNER is an ideal man for the job, but he doesn't want it. The

Dreyfuss may select Hans Lobert or Larry Doyle if either can be procured.
’ Tyrus Cobb Seems to Have Clinched Batting Honors

2 pate race for batting honors in the American League is about over. Tyrus Cobb
has taken a commanding lead, and now that he is working his head off and
taking his job seriously, it's hard to figure how he will be headed by the other
@mbitious swatsmen. Tris Speaker is rolling along at a consistent gait and others
in the .300 class, but the space between them and the leader is wide enough
to drive Jimmy Dougherty's car through, ‘Terrible Tyrus is out to lead the league
and he will have his wish.
We all know that Thumping Tyrus is a remarkable player and his crafty
‘Work on the diamond makes him one of the greatest players of all time. How-
, some of the old-timers maintain that he cannot compare with the famous
King Kelly, of twenty years ago. Kelly, by the way, played an entirely different
‘game from Cobb. The old boy was a shrewd player and pulled many original
@tunts which never have been duplicated. One day Kelly was managing from
the bench. It was a close game and the opponents were at bat for the last time
; the heaviest hitter at the plate. A hit would tle the score and a long wallop
mean victory Like the others, Kelly was very nervous at this stage of
game.
An old-timer named Silver Flint was catching and the heavy hitter was begin-
iw to find the range to the left field fence. He knocked several out of the lot, but
(they were foul, and Kelly's men were fast losing confidence. Finally the batter
hit a fast foul which traveled straight at the players’ bench. Kelly grasped the
ituation at a glance, leaped to his feet and yelled:
“Flint out! ¢Kelly now catching!”
Then he caught the bal! for the third out and the game was saved.
. . .
AT stunt couldn't be pulled nowadays, but there was nothing in the
rules then to prevent a substitution even in the midst of play and Kelly
was foxy enough to take advantage of it. The King’s favorite caper was
‘to do things for the first time. The rule-makers never did catch up to him.
At That, Kelly Was a Wonderful Player in His Day

JN THE dark ages Kelly was one of the best base runners the game ever knew.
He wasn't fast, but took a whale of a lead and could slide into the base with as
\ speed and dash as Cobb. That ever green “Slide, Kelly Slide,” yodel which
extensively by every sand-lotter dates back to the sliding days of Kelly.
played with Anson's White Stockings and later was the star of the Boston
. He was so good that they used to say that he boxed with his feet.

nother of Kelly’s immortal plays, according to Harold Wilcox, who dug up
, was achieved in the world series of 1892. That was the year that the
League tried the split-season scheme. Cleveland won the championship
first season and Boston snagged the flag for the second half. The first
if the world series’ went eleven innings to a scoreless tie. Then Boston won
ht. Jesse Burkett was on third base in the game in question. Two were
batter grounded to Herman Long, who shortstopped for the eastern
was slow and threw to First Baseman Tommy Tucker a trifle too

r dashed for-home at the crack of the bat.
was catching, He caught the situation like a flash. As the ball reached
f down his mitt and started for the bench. Burkett knew the Play at
yas close and guessed from Kelly's stunt that the runner had been called out.
up. Kelly spun around and yelled for the ball. Tucker had his head
were the ball home. Kelly caught it with his bare hands, blocking
of plate meanwhile, and applied the onion where it would do the
4. Burkett was out, and one of the few close games of that world series

are again in a jam. After virtually
making @ runaway of the Delaware County
League race, Frank Poth's aggregation of
high-priced talent is gradually falling by the
wayside The Upland nine, piloted by
another Frank, with Miller at the finish,
is coming with a rush and on the morning
of July 4th, in the City of Chester, the two
teams meet again, A run for the town
made famous by home-run Baker will tie
up the race and on the other hand a victory
for Chester gives that club the gonfalon
in the Weeks's circult for the first half,
which ends with the Fourth of July.

The Upland squad, at this writing, is
playing the best game. It has lost three
games, a8 against two for its opponents,
but the brand of ball flashed by the
former champions is of a higher stand-
ard. This is disclosed by a glance at the
records. Although Chester has the best
of the series, two to one, the Upland boys
have outhit their opponents by a fair mar-
gin in the three games played.

Since Decoration Day the runners-up
have been flashing the best ball in the
league. On that occasion they dropped
two encounters, losing to Brill in the a. m.,
canter by the lop-sided total of 1243, and
peed beaten by Cheater in the p. m) affair

NOTED CRICKETERS FOUND
IN LATE CASUALTY LIST

LONDON, July 1,—Several well- y
county cricketers figure secntinbene og
latest casualty list issued, as the result of
the severe fighting on the Western front
J, W. Rothery, the famous Yorkshire County
player, has been wounded seriously in the
left arm. His finest performance was
against Kent, at Dover, in 1908, when he
saved his side from certain defeat by put-
ting together a brilliant inning of 161 runs

Major H. W. Persse, who Played regu-
larly for the Hampshire County Club in
1906 and 1908, has also been badly
wounded, The death of Major H. G Black
lidge will be seriously felt by the famous
Surrey County Club, for which he did exce]
on: work in past seasons A

AFTER MANY WEARY YEARS OF
FRUITLESS TRAVAIL COMISKEY HAS
SWELL CHANCE TO LAND BUNTING

By GRANTLAND RICE
AN OLD ONE—REVISED
(In view of the umpirical situation these past few weeks—featuring Byron
The game that day from round to round had been a scrappy fight;
The home club and the visitora had battled close to night; ;
The visitora had tallied in the fourteenth round at last,
And, while the chance for victory seemed pretty nearly past,
The frenzied fans in chorna, with the old-time woolly roar,
Rose un and clamored madly for at least the teing score,
The firat two fanned the breezes, bul the last quy caught one good.
He cuffed it an the trademark and it bounded off the wood;
The Rugs stood up and hellowed aa he slid into the plate,
And hailed the doughty hero who had blocked their hitter fate:
The umpire paused a moment as he looked around in doubt,
And then, in shaking, quaking vorce, exclaimed, “The runner's out!”
That night his wife awaited him, quite pained at hir delay,
Until ahe qot a little note which theae nad words did say:

“Honey, dear, listen here, I'm afraid to qo homa from the par
Every day the papers say ‘there's anu mpire sluqaed for a lar
So here 1 sit in the clubhouse alone, wailing aloud in the dark:
There's no place like home, sweet home,
But I’m afraid to go home in the dark.”

Three years ago today the Boston
Braves were in last place, Starting just at
this time, through some wild psychological
upheaval, they ran amuck through the re
mainder of the year, dismantling the
National League and dismembering the
Mackmen,

This stand
sport. But the flame
too fiercely to last

upheaval tn
must have burned
long. The Battling
Braves have never won a pennant since,
and here they are hopelessly out of the
race by July, beaten and broken, with no
chance to repeat that once spectacular ad-
vance,

Injuries to Johnny Evers and the passing
of Bill James were contributing causes, but
that one wild march also seems to have
burned out the old fire. They knew one

Revised Again—
Lives of Prussians oft remind ’em
How their legions play the game,
And, departing, leave behind ’em
Everything in blood and fame.

Let us, then, be up and doing,
As we dive into the wreck,
Still achieving, still pursuing,
Till we grab ’em by the neck.
